kpi_framework.description: KPI definitions following the Acquisition → Activation → Retention → Revenue framework

acquisition.description: How users discover and arrive at your product

kpis.name: Traffic Volume
kpis.definition: Total number of unique visitors to landing page or app store listing

kpis.name: Traffic by Channel
kpis.definition: Breakdown of where users come from (organic, paid, referral, direct)

kpis.name: Signup Starts
kpis.definition: Number of users who begin the signup process

activation.description: Users experience core value and complete setup

kpis.name: Signup Conversion Rate
kpis.definition: % of signup attempts that complete successfully

kpis.name: Activation Rate
kpis.definition: % of new users who reach 'aha moment' or complete onboarding
kpis.measurement: Percentage within first session or first 24 hours
kpis.notes: Define 'activation' based on core value prop (e.g., 'created first release' for a release notes product)

kpis.name: Time to Activation
kpis.definition: Average time from signup to activation event
kpis.good_target: <5 minutes for SaaS, <1 hour for complex products
kpis.data_source: Time difference between signup_completed and user_activated timestamps

retention.description: Users come back and continue using the product

kpis.name: Day 1 Retention (D1)
kpis.definition: % of users who return the day after signup

kpis.name: Day 7 Retention (D7)
kpis.definition: % of users who return within 7 days of signup

kpis.name: Day 30 Retention (D30)
kpis.definition: % of users who return within 30 days of signup

kpis.name: Weekly Active Users (WAU)
kpis.definition: Number of unique users active in the past 7 days

kpis.name: Monthly Active Users (MAU)
kpis.definition: Number of unique users active in the past 30 days

kpis.name: Churn Rate
kpis.definition: % of users who stop using the product in a given period

revenue.description: Users pay for the product or generate revenue

kpis.name: Conversion to Paid
kpis.definition: % of free users who become paying customers

kpis.name: Average Revenue Per User (ARPU)
kpis.definition: Total revenue divided by number of users
kpis.good_target: Depends on pricing model; track trend

kpis.name: Customer Lifetime Value (LTV)
kpis.definition: Predicted total revenue from a customer over their lifetime
kpis.good_target: LTV should be 3x+ customer acquisition cost (CAC)
example_events: All revenue events over customer lifetime

kpis.name: Monthly Recurring Revenue (MRR)
kpis.definition: Predictable revenue from subscriptions each month
kpis.calculation: Sum of all active subscription values normalized to monthly

kpis.name: Customer Acquisition Cost (CAC)
kpis.definition: Total cost to acquire one new customer

kpis.name: Session Duration
kpis.definition: Average time a user spends in the app per session

kpis.name: Feature Adoption Rate
kpis.definition: % of users who use a specific feature

kpis.name: Stickiness (DAU/MAU)
kpis.definition: Ratio of daily active users to monthly active users

example_one_metric_that_matters.description: Choose ONE primary metric per cycle based on product stage

early_stage_0_to_1.why: Need to prove users get value before optimizing growth
early_stage_0_to_1.target: 30% of signups activate (complete onboarding + create first release) within first session

growth_stage.why: Activation is proven; now focus on growing user base

retention_stage.why: User growth is strong; need to keep them coming back

monetization_stage.why: Retention is solid; time to monetize
monetization_stage.target: 3% of free users convert to paid within 30 days

usage_notes: Not all KPIs are relevant at all stages. Focus on 3-5 KPIs per cycle.
Always have ONE primary metric (OMTM) per cycle or sprint.
Define your 'activation event' based on core value (e.g., 'created first release', 'sent first message').
Track anti-metrics (e.g., signup conversion shouldn't tank while optimizing activation).
Industry benchmarks vary; use these as guidelines, not absolutes.
